mn75:1.1.comm: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya appears outraged at the presence of the Buddha, who he thinks stands in opposition to life itself since he opposes sensual enjoyment. It soon turns out that he misunderstands the Buddha’s teachings on sensuality, as the Buddha’s aim is not to prevent people from experiencing pleasure but to elevate them so they can enjoy a higher form of pleasure.

mn75:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo, bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa agyāgāre tiṇasanthārake.
mn75:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma, on a grass mat in the fire chamber of a brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan.

mn75:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kammāsadhammaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn75:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kammāsadamma for alms.

mn75:2.2.pli: Kammāsadhammaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena aññataro vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
mn75:2.2.eng: He wandered for alms in Kammāsadamma. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.

mn75:2.3.pli: Taṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
mn75:2.3.eng: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.

mn75:3.1.pli: Atha kho māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa agyāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
mn75:3.1.eng: Then as the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya was going for a walk he approached that fire chamber.
mn75:3.1.comm: A Māgaṇḍiya appears here and in Snp 4.9, where he uses his beautiful daughter to tempt the Buddha (cited and discussed at SN 22.3). As to the protagonist of Snp 4.9, the Pali commentary, Divyāvadāna 36—which calls him Mākandika—and the Chinese parallel in the Arthapada (T iv 180) say he too was from the Kuru country. Now, the Mahābhārata and other Sanskrit sources name Mākandī as a city or province on the banks of the Ganges, in the Pañcāla kingdom south of Hastināpura. This more-or-less agrees with Māgaṇḍiya’s home in the Kuru country, and suggests his name means “the man from Mākandī”. Divyāvadāna 36 and Sanskrit fragment say the Mākandika of Snp 4.9 was also a wanderer, which does not contradict the position of the Pali commentaries and the Arthapada that he was a brahmin. At AN 5.294–302:1.1, māgaṇḍika is listed as a type of ascetic; these could well be students of Māgaṇḍiya. Kathāsaritsāgara 15 tells the comic farce of an ascetic from Mākandikā on the banks of the Ganges, who fell in love with the daughter of a merchant and went to ridiculous lengths to obtain her, only to end up a laughing-stock. This story could well have begun life as a comic inversion of Snp 4.9. Reading all these sources together, we can posit that there was a brahmin wanderer from Mākandī on the Ganges in Kuru-Pañcāla, who gained a certain fame and following as a teacher, but whose hedonism was his downfall. The Pali commentaries further specify that the Māgaṇḍiya of the current sutta is the nephew of the one at Snp 4.9.

mn75:3.2.pli: Addasā kho māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa agyāgāre tiṇasanthārakaṃ paññattaṃ.
mn75:3.2.eng: He saw the grass mat spread out there

mn75:3.3.eng: and asked the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan,

mn75:3.4.pli: “kassa nvayaṃ bhoto bhāradvājassa agyāgāre tiṇasanthārako paññatto, samaṇaseyyānurūpaṃ maññe”ti?
mn75:3.4.eng: “Worthy Bhāradvāja, who has this grass mat been spread out for? It looks like an ascetic’s bed.”

mn75:4.1.pli: “Atthi, bho māgaṇḍiya, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito.
mn75:4.1.eng: “There is the ascetic Gotama, a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family.

mn75:4.2.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn75:4.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn75:4.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn75:4.4.eng: This bed has been spread for that worthy Gotama.”

mn75:5.1.eng: “Well, it’s a sad sight, worthy Bhāradvāja,

mn75:5.3.pli: Ye mayaṃ tassa bhoto gotamassa bhūnahuno seyyaṃ addasāmā”ti.
mn75:5.3.eng: to see a bed for the worthy Gotama, that baby-killer!”
mn75:5.3.comm: Bhūnahan is Sanskrit bhrūṇahan. The earliest sense is “fetus-killer”, found in Rig Veda 10.155.2a where a grotesque demoness is cursed as one who “slays all fetuses” (sarvā bhrūṇāny āruṣī), and also at Atharvaveda 6.1112.3c (bhrūṇaghni). They are listed among heinous folk at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.22 (Olivelle: “abortionist”). Later it took on the sense “murderer of a brahmin”. It is used in Pali for a depraved person, especially one who destroys the life of a developed fetus or child (see AN 7.64:22.1, Ja 358:1.1, Ja 544:105.2). | The brahmin of Verañja calls the Buddha a variety of names at AN 8.11.

mn75:5.6.pli: Bahū hi tassa bhoto gotamassa khattiyapaṇḍitāpi brāhmaṇapaṇḍitāpi gahapatipaṇḍitāpi samaṇapaṇḍitāpi abhippasannā vinītā ariye ñāye dhamme kusale”ti.
mn75:5.6.eng: Many astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics are devoted to the worthy Gotama. They’ve been guided by him in the noble system, the skillful teaching.”

mn75:5.7.pli: “Sammukhā cepi mayaṃ, bho bhāradvāja, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ passeyyāma, sammukhāpi naṃ vadeyyāma:
mn75:5.7.eng: “Even if I was to see the worthy Gotama face to face, worthy Bhāradvāja, I would say to his face:

mn75:5.10.eng: For so it came to me while sleeping.”
mn75:5.10.comm: Sutta can mean “discourse” or “sleeping”. I do not know anywhere else in the Pali where non-Buddhist texts are referred to as sutta. Further, it would seem unlikely that they had such a prophecy of the Buddha, and no early Brahmanical texts have anything like this. On the other hand, the Upaniṣads feature many passages on sleep and dream, and the importance of the visions therein (eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.18). Also, avacarati is not, so far as I know, used for the “transmission” of scripture, but it is used for the “descent” from heaven (Rig Veda 10.59.9a), a usage fitting well the appearance of a vision in a dream. | The plural no (“our”) here is not significant, as Māgaṇḍiya refers to himself with the royal “we”.

mn75:5.11.pli: “Sace taṃ bhoto māgaṇḍiyassa agaru āroceyyāmi taṃ samaṇassa gotamassā”ti.
mn75:5.11.eng: “If you don’t mind, I’ll tell the ascetic Gotama about this.”

mn75:5.12.eng: “Don’t worry, worthy Bhāradvāja. You may tell him exactly what I’ve said.”

mn75:6.1.pli: Assosi kho bhagavā dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa māgaṇḍiyena paribbājakena saddhiṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ.
mn75:6.1.eng: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard this discussion between the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan and the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya.

mn75:6.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa agyāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nisīdi bhagavā paññatte tiṇasanthārake.
mn75:6.2.eng: Coming out of retreat, he went to the brahmin’s fire chamber and sat on the grass mat.

mn75:6.3.pli: Atha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn75:6.3.eng: Then the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

mn75:6.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho bhāradvājagottaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn75:6.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

mn75:6.5.pli: “ahu pana te, bhāradvāja, māgaṇḍiyena paribbājakena saddhiṃ imaṃyeva tiṇasanthārakaṃ ārabbha kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
mn75:6.5.eng: “Bhāradvāja, did you have a discussion with the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya about this grass mat?”

mn75:6.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn75:6.6.eng: When he said this, the brahmin, shocked and awestruck, said to the Buddha,

mn75:6.7.pli: “etadeva kho pana mayaṃ bhoto gotamassa ārocetukāmā.
mn75:6.7.eng: “I wanted to mention this very thing to the worthy Gotama,

mn75:6.8.pli: Atha ca pana bhavaṃ gotamo anakkhātaṃyeva akkhāsī”ti.
mn75:6.8.eng: but you brought it up before I had a chance.”

mn75:7.1.pli: Ayañca hi bhagavato bhāradvājagottena brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ antarākathā vippakatā hoti.
mn75:7.1.eng: But this conversation between the Buddha and the brahmin was left unfinished.

mn75:7.2.pli: Atha kho māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa agyāgāraṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn75:7.2.eng: Then as the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya was going for a walk he approached that fire chamber. He went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn75:7.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho māgaṇḍiyaṃ paribbājakaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn75:7.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the Buddha said to him:

mn75:8.1.eng: “Māgaṇḍiya, the eye likes sights, it loves them and enjoys them.

mn75:8.2.pli: Taṃ tathāgatassa dantaṃ guttaṃ rakkhitaṃ saṃvutaṃ, tassa ca saṃvarāya dhammaṃ deseti.
mn75:8.2.eng: That’s been tamed, guarded, protected and restrained by the Realized One, and he teaches Dhamma for its restraint.

mn75:8.3.pli: Idaṃ nu te etaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn75:8.3.eng: Is that what you were referring to when you called me

mn75:8.5.pli: “Etadeva kho pana me, bho gotama, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn75:8.5.eng: “That’s exactly what I was referring to.

mn75:8.8.eng: For so it came to me while sleeping.”

mn75:8.11.pli: jivhā kho, māgaṇḍiya, rasārāmā rasaratā rasasammuditā.

mn75:8.12.pli: Sā tathāgatassa dantā guttā rakkhitā saṃvutā, tassā ca saṃvarāya dhammaṃ deseti.

mn75:8.13.pli: Idaṃ nu te etaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:

mn75:8.15.pli: “Etadeva kho pana me, bho gotama, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:

mn75:8.20.pli: mano kho, māgaṇḍiya, dhammārāmo dhammarato dhammasammudito.
mn75:8.20.eng: The mind likes ideas, it loves them and enjoys them.

mn75:8.21.pli: So tathāgatassa danto gutto rakkhito saṃvuto, tassa ca saṃvarāya dhammaṃ deseti.
mn75:8.21.eng: That’s been tamed, guarded, protected and restrained by the Realized One, and he teaches Dhamma for its restraint.

mn75:8.22.pli: Idaṃ nu te etaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn75:8.22.eng: Is that what you were referring to when you called me

mn75:8.24.pli: “Etadeva kho pana me, bho gotama, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn75:8.24.eng: “That’s exactly what I was referring to.

mn75:8.27.eng: For so it came to me while sleeping.”

mn75:9.2.pli: ‘idhekacco cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi paricāritapubbo assa iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi, so aparena samayena rūpānaṃyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā rūpataṇhaṃ pahāya rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto vihareyya.
mn75:9.2.eng: Take someone who used to amuse themselves with sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sights, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sights—they would live rid of thirst, their mind peaceful inside.

mn75:9.3.pli: Imassa pana te, māgaṇḍiya, kimassa vacanīyan’”ti?
mn75:9.3.eng: What would you have to say to them, Māgaṇḍiya?”

mn75:9.6.eng: Take someone who used to amuse themselves with sounds known by the ear …

mn75:9.9.pli: kāyaviññeyyehi phoṭṭhabbehi paricāritapubbo assa iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi,
mn75:9.9.eng: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn75:9.10.pli: so aparena samayena phoṭṭhabbānaṃyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā phoṭṭhabbataṇhaṃ pahāya phoṭṭhabbapariḷāhaṃ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto vihareyya.
mn75:9.10.eng: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of touches, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for touches—they would live rid of thirst, their mind peaceful inside.

mn75:9.11.pli: Imassa pana te, māgaṇḍiya, kimassa vacanīyan’”ti?
mn75:9.11.eng: What would you have to say to them, Māgaṇḍiya?”

mn75:10.1.pli: “Ahaṃ kho pana, māgaṇḍiya, pubbe agāriyabhūto samāno pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāresiṃ cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi, sotaviññeyyehi saddehi …pe…
mn75:10.1.eng: “Well, when I was still a layperson I used to amuse myself, supplied and provided with sights known by the eye … sounds known by the ear …

mn75:10.4.pli: kāyaviññeyyehi phoṭṭhabbehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi.
mn75:10.4.eng: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn75:10.5.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, tayo pāsādā ahesuṃ—

mn75:10.6.pli: eko vassiko, eko hemantiko, eko gimhiko.
mn75:10.6.eng: one for the rainy season, one for the winter, and one for the summer.

mn75:10.7.pli: So kho ahaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, vassike pāsāde vassike cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ orohāmi.
mn75:10.7.eng: I stayed in a stilt longhouse without coming downstairs for the four months of the rainy season, where I was entertained by musicians—none of them men.

mn75:10.8.pli: So aparena samayena kāmānaṃyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā kāmataṇhaṃ pahāya kāmapariḷāhaṃ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto viharāmi.
mn75:10.8.eng: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sensual pleasures—I live rid of thirst, my mind peaceful inside.

mn75:10.9.pli: So aññe satte passāmi kāmesu avītarāge kāmataṇhāhi khajjamāne kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāne kāme paṭisevante.
mn75:10.9.eng: I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures.

mn75:10.10.pli: So tesaṃ na pihemi, na tattha abhiramāmi.
mn75:10.10.eng: I don’t envy them, nor do I hope to enjoy that.

mn75:10.12.pli: Yāhayaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, rati, aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi—
mn75:10.12.eng: Because there is a satisfaction that is apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities,

mn75:10.13.comm: Samadhigayha tiṭṭhati means “stands at the same level”, “equals” not “surpasses” (Iti 23:2.1, MN 78:8.8).

mn75:10.14.pli: tāya ratiyā ramamāno hīnassa na pihemi, na tattha abhiramāmi.
mn75:10.14.eng: Enjoying that satisfaction, I don’t envy what is inferior, nor do I hope to enjoy it.

mn75:11.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, māgaṇḍiya, gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreyya cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi …
mn75:11.1.eng: Suppose there was a householder or a householder’s child who was rich, affluent, and wealthy. And they would amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. That is, sights known by the eye …

mn75:11.3.pli: phoṭṭhabbehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi.
mn75:11.3.eng: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn75:11.4.pli: So kāyena sucaritaṃ caritvā vācāya sucaritaṃ caritvā manasā sucaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
mn75:11.4.eng: Having practiced good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, when their body breaks up, after death, they’d be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

mn75:11.5.pli: So tattha nandane vane accharāsaṅghaparivuto dibbehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreyya.
mn75:11.5.eng: There they’d amuse themselves in the Garden of Delight, escorted by a band of nymphs, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation.

mn75:11.6.pli: So passeyya gahapatiṃ vā gahapatiputtaṃ vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaṃ samaṅgībhūtaṃ paricārayamānaṃ.
mn75:11.6.eng: Then they’d see a householder or a householder’s child amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn75:11.7.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, māgaṇḍiya, api nu so devaputto nandane vane accharāsaṅghaparivuto dibbehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricārayamāno amussa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā piheyya, mānusakānaṃ vā pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ mānusakehi vā kāmehi āvaṭṭeyyā”ti?
mn75:11.7.eng: What do you think, Māgaṇḍiya? Would that god—amusing themselves in the Garden of Delight, escorted by a band of nymphs, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation—envy that householder or householder’s child their five kinds of human sensual stimulation, or return to human sensual pleasures?”

mn75:11.10.pli: Mānusakehi, bho gotama, kāmehi dibbakāmā abhikkantatarā ca paṇītatarā cā”ti.
mn75:11.10.eng: Because heavenly sensual pleasures are better than human sensual pleasures.”

mn75:12.1.pli: “Evameva kho ahaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, pubbe agāriyabhūto samāno pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāresiṃ cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi, sotaviññeyyehi saddehi …pe…
mn75:12.1.eng: “In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, when I was still a layperson I used to entertain myself with sights … sounds …

mn75:12.4.pli: kāyaviññeyyehi phoṭṭhabbehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi.
mn75:12.4.eng: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn75:12.5.pli: So aparena samayena kāmānaṃyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā kāmataṇhaṃ pahāya kāmapariḷāhaṃ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto viharāmi.
mn75:12.5.eng: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sensual pleasures—I live rid of thirst, my mind peaceful inside.

mn75:12.6.pli: So aññe satte passāmi kāmesu avītarāge kāmataṇhāhi khajjamāne kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāne kāme paṭisevante, so tesaṃ na pihemi, na tattha abhiramāmi.
mn75:12.6.eng: I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures. I don’t envy them, nor do I hope to enjoy that.

mn75:12.8.pli: Yāhayaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, rati aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi—
mn75:12.8.eng: Because there is a satisfaction that is apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities,

mn75:12.10.pli: tāya ratiyā ramamāno hīnassa na pihemi, na tattha abhiramāmi.
mn75:12.10.eng: Enjoying that satisfaction, I don’t envy what is inferior, nor do I hope to enjoy it.

mn75:13.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, māgaṇḍiya, kuṭṭhī puriso arugatto pakkagatto kimīhi khajjamāno nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamāno aṅgārakāsuyā kāyaṃ paritāpeyya.
mn75:13.1.eng: Suppose there was a person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, they’d cauterize their body over a pit of glowing coals.
mn75:13.1.comm: “Person affected by leprosy” is kuṭṭhī puriso

mn75:13.2.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn75:13.2.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn75:13.3.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto bhesajjaṃ kareyya.
mn75:13.3.eng: The surgeon would make medicine for them,

mn75:13.4.pli: So taṃ bhesajjaṃ āgamma kuṭṭhehi parimucceyya, arogo assa sukhī serī sayaṃvasī yena kāmaṃ gamo.
mn75:13.4.eng: and by using that they’d be cured of leprosy. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.

mn75:13.5.pli: So aññaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ purisaṃ passeyya arugattaṃ pakkagattaṃ kimīhi khajjamānaṃ nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamānaṃ aṅgārakāsuyā kāyaṃ paritāpentaṃ.
mn75:13.5.eng: Then they’d see another person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs, being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, cauterizing their body over a pit of glowing coals.

mn75:13.7.pli: api nu so puriso amussa kuṭṭhissa purisassa piheyya aṅgārakāsuyā vā bhesajjaṃ paṭisevanāya vā”ti?
mn75:13.7.eng: Would that person envy that other person affected by leprosy for their pit of glowing coals or for taking medicine?”

mn75:13.10.pli: Roge hi, bho gotama, sati bhesajjena karaṇīyaṃ hoti, roge asati na bhesajjena karaṇīyaṃ hotī”ti.
mn75:13.10.eng: Because you need to take medicine only when there’s a disease. When there’s no disease, there’s no need for medicine.”

mn75:14.1.pli: “Evameva kho ahaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, pubbe agāriyabhūto samāno pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāresiṃ, cakkhuviññeyyehi rūpehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi, sotaviññeyyehi saddehi …pe…
mn75:14.1.eng: “In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, when I was still a layperson I used to entertain myself with sights … sounds …

mn75:14.4.pli: kāyaviññeyyehi phoṭṭhabbehi iṭṭhehi kantehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi rajanīyehi.
mn75:14.4.eng: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn75:14.5.pli: So aparena samayena kāmānaṃyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā kāmataṇhaṃ pahāya kāmapariḷāhaṃ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto viharāmi.
mn75:14.5.eng: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sensual pleasures—I live rid of thirst, my mind peaceful inside.

mn75:14.6.pli: So aññe satte passāmi kāmesu avītarāge kāmataṇhāhi khajjamāne kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāne kāme paṭisevante.
mn75:14.6.eng: I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures.

mn75:14.7.pli: So tesaṃ na pihemi, na tattha abhiramāmi.
mn75:14.7.eng: I don’t envy them, nor do I hope to enjoy that.

mn75:14.9.pli: Yāhayaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, rati, aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi—
mn75:14.9.eng: Because there is a satisfaction that is apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities,

mn75:14.11.pli: tāya ratiyā ramamāno hīnassa na pihemi, na tattha abhiramāmi.
mn75:14.11.eng: Enjoying that satisfaction, I don’t envy what is inferior, nor do I hope to enjoy it.

mn75:15.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, māgaṇḍiya, kuṭṭhī puriso arugatto pakkagatto kimīhi khajjamāno nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamāno aṅgārakāsuyā kāyaṃ paritāpeyya.
mn75:15.1.eng: Suppose there was a person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, they’d cauterize their body over a pit of glowing coals.

mn75:15.2.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn75:15.2.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn75:15.3.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto bhesajjaṃ kareyya.
mn75:15.3.eng: The surgeon would make medicine for them,

mn75:15.4.pli: So taṃ bhesajjaṃ āgamma kuṭṭhehi parimucceyya, arogo assa sukhī serī sayaṃvasī yena kāmaṃ gamo.
mn75:15.4.eng: and by using that they’d be cured of leprosy. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.

mn75:15.5.pli: Tamenaṃ dve balavanto purisā nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuṃ upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.
mn75:15.5.eng: Two strong men would grab them by the arms and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals.

mn75:15.7.pli: api nu so puriso iti citiceva kāyaṃ sannāmeyyā”ti?
mn75:15.7.eng: Wouldn’t that person writhe and struggle to and fro?”

mn75:15.10.pli: Asu hi, bho gotama, aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho cā”ti.
mn75:15.10.eng: Because that fire is really painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching.”

mn75:15.12.pli: idāneva nu kho so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho ca udāhu pubbepi so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho cā”ti?
mn75:15.12.eng: Is it only now that the fire is really painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching, or was it painful previously as well?”

mn75:15.13.pli: “Idāni ceva, bho gotama, so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho ca, pubbepi so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho ca.
mn75:15.13.eng: “That fire is painful now and it was also painful previously.

mn75:15.14.pli: Asu ca, bho gotama, kuṭṭhī puriso arugatto pakkagatto kimīhi khajjamāno nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamāno upahatindriyo dukkhasamphasseyeva aggismiṃ sukhamiti viparītasaññaṃ paccalatthā”ti.
mn75:15.14.eng: That person was affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, their sense faculties were impaired. So even though the fire was actually painful to touch, they had a distorted perception that it was pleasant.”

mn75:16.1.pli: “Evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, atītampi addhānaṃ kāmā dukkhasamphassā ceva mahābhitāpā ca mahāpariḷāhā ca, anāgatampi addhānaṃ kāmā dukkhasamphassā ceva mahābhitāpā ca mahāpariḷāhā ca, etarahipi paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ kāmā dukkhasamphassā ceva mahābhitāpā ca mahāpariḷāhā ca.
mn75:16.1.eng: “In the same way, sensual pleasures of the past, future, and present are painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching.

mn75:16.2.pli: Ime ca, māgaṇḍiya, sattā kāmesu avītarāgā kāmataṇhāhi khajjamānā kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamānā upahatindriyā dukkhasamphassesuyeva kāmesu sukhamiti viparītasaññaṃ paccalatthuṃ.
mn75:16.2.eng: These sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures—being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures—have impaired sense faculties. So even though sensual pleasures are actually painful to touch, they have a distorted perception that they are pleasant.

mn75:17.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, māgaṇḍiya, kuṭṭhī puriso arugatto pakkagatto kimīhi khajjamāno nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamāno aṅgārakāsuyā kāyaṃ paritāpeti.
mn75:17.1.eng: Suppose there was a person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, they’re cauterizing their body over a pit of glowing coals.

mn75:17.2.pli: Yathā yathā kho, māgaṇḍiya, asu kuṭṭhī puriso arugatto pakkagatto kimīhi khajjamāno nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamāno aṅgārakāsuyā kāyaṃ paritāpeti tathā tathāssa tāni vaṇamukhāni asucitarāni ceva honti duggandhatarāni ca pūtikatarāni ca, hoti ceva kāci sātamattā assādamattā—yadidaṃ vaṇamukhānaṃ kaṇḍūvanahetu;
mn75:17.2.eng: The more they scratch their wounds and cauterize their body, the more their wounds become foul, stinking, and infected. But still, they derive a degree of pleasure and gratification from the itchiness of their wounds.

mn75:17.3.pli: evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, sattā kāmesu avītarāgā kāmataṇhāhi khajjamānā kāmapariḷāhena ca pariḍayhamānā kāme paṭisevanti.
mn75:17.3.eng: In the same way, I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures.

mn75:17.4.pli: Yathā yathā kho, māgaṇḍiya, sattā kāmesu avītarāgā kāmataṇhāhi khajjamānā kāmapariḷāhena ca pariḍayhamānā kāme paṭisevanti tathā tathā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ kāmataṇhā ceva pavaḍḍhati, kāmapariḷāhena ca pariḍayhanti, hoti ceva sātamattā assādamattā—yadidaṃ pañcakāmaguṇe paṭicca.
mn75:17.4.eng: The more they indulge in sensual pleasures, the more their craving for sensual pleasures grows, and the more they burn with passion for sensual pleasures. But still, they derive a degree of pleasure and gratification from the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn75:18.2.pli: api nu te diṭṭho vā suto vā rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricārayamāno kāmataṇhaṃ appahāya kāmapariḷāhaṃ appaṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto vihāsi vā viharati vā viharissati vā”ti?
mn75:18.2.eng: Have you seen or heard of a king or a royal minister of the past, future, or present, amusing themselves supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, who—without giving up craving for sensual pleasures and dispelling passion for sensual pleasures—lives rid of thirst, their mind peaceful inside?”

mn75:18.5.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, neva diṭṭhaṃ na sutaṃ rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricārayamāno kāmataṇhaṃ appahāya kāmapariḷāhaṃ appaṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto vihāsi vā viharati vā viharissati vā.

mn75:18.6.pli: Atha kho, māgaṇḍiya, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā vigatapipāsā ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacittā vihāsuṃ vā viharanti vā viharissanti vā sabbe te kāmānaṃyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā kāmataṇhaṃ pahāya kāmapariḷāhaṃ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāsā ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacittā vihāsuṃ vā viharanti vā viharissanti vā”ti.
mn75:18.6.eng: On the contrary, all the ascetics or brahmins of the past, future, or present who live rid of thirst, their minds peaceful inside, do so after truly understanding the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and after giving up craving and dispelling passion for sensual pleasures.”

mn75:19.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
mn75:19.1.eng: Then on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

mn75:19.2.comm: The first two lines appear also as the first and last lines of Dhp 204, as well as in many parallels for that verse.

mn75:19.4.eng: Of paths, the ultimate is eightfold—

mn75:19.5.eng: it’s safe, and leads to freedom from death.”

mn75:19.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn75:19.6.eng: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya said to him,

mn75:19.8.eng: How well said this was by the worthy Gotama!

mn75:19.9.eng: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’

mn75:19.10.pli: Mayāpi kho etaṃ, bho gotama, sutaṃ pubbakānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
mn75:19.10.eng: I’ve also heard that wanderers of the past, the tutors of tutors, said:

mn75:19.11.eng: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’
mn75:19.11.comm: I have not been able to trace such a saying. Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.4.2 identifies the supreme divinity as “ultimate happiness”.

mn75:19.13.pli: “Yaṃ pana te etaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, sutaṃ pubbakānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
mn75:19.13.eng: “But Māgaṇḍiya, when you heard that wanderers of the past said this,

mn75:19.14.pli: ‘ārogyaparamā lābhā, nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukhan’ti, katamaṃ taṃ ārogyaṃ, katamaṃ taṃ nibbānan”ti?
mn75:19.14.eng: what is that health? And what is that extinguishment?”

mn75:19.15.pli: Evaṃ vutte, māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako sakāneva sudaṃ gattāni pāṇinā anomajjati:
mn75:19.15.eng: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya stroked his own limbs with his hands, saying:

mn75:19.16.eng: “This is that health, worthy Gotama, this is that extinguishment!

mn75:19.17.pli: Ahañhi, bho gotama, etarahi arogo sukhī, na maṃ kiñci ābādhatī”ti.
mn75:19.17.eng: For I am now healthy and happy, and have no afflictions.”

mn75:20.1.eng: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.

mn75:20.2.pli: so na passeyya kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṃ, na passeyya tārakarūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.
mn75:20.2.eng: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.

mn75:20.3.eng: They might hear a sighted person saying:

mn75:20.4.pli: ‘chekaṃ vata, bho, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti.
mn75:20.4.eng: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’

mn75:20.5.eng: They’d go in search of white cloth.

mn75:20.6.pli: Tamenaṃ aññataro puriso telamalikatena sāhuḷicīrena vañceyya:
mn75:20.6.eng: But someone would cheat them with a dirty, soiled garment, saying:

mn75:20.7.pli: ‘idaṃ te, ambho purisa, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti.
mn75:20.7.eng: ‘Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’

mn75:20.8.pli: So taṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, paṭiggahetvā pārupeyya, pārupetvā attamano attamanavācaṃ nicchāreyya:
mn75:20.8.eng: They’d take it and put it on, expressing their gladness:

mn75:20.9.pli: ‘chekaṃ vata, bho, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti.
mn75:20.9.eng: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’

mn75:20.11.pli: api nu so jaccandho puriso jānanto passanto amuṃ telamalikataṃ sāhuḷicīraṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, paṭiggahetvā pārupeyya, pārupetvā attamano attamanavācaṃ nicchāreyya:
mn75:20.11.eng: Did that person blind from birth do this knowing and seeing,

mn75:20.12.pli: ‘chekaṃ vata, bho, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti udāhu cakkhumato saddhāyā”ti?
mn75:20.12.eng: or out of faith in the sighted person?”

mn75:20.13.pli: “Ajānanto hi, bho gotama, apassanto so jaccandho puriso amuṃ telamalikataṃ sāhuḷicīraṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, paṭiggahetvā pārupeyya, pārupetvā attamano attamanavācaṃ nicchāreyya:
mn75:20.13.eng: “They did so not knowing or seeing,

mn75:20.14.pli: ‘chekaṃ vata, bho, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti, cakkhumato saddhāyā”ti.
mn75:20.14.eng: but out of faith in the sighted person.”

mn75:21.1.pli: “Evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā andhā acakkhukā ajānantā ārogyaṃ, apassantā nibbānaṃ, atha ca panimaṃ gāthaṃ bhāsanti:
mn75:21.1.eng: “In the same way, the wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless. Not knowing health and not seeing extinguishment, they still recite this verse:

mn75:21.2.eng: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’

mn75:21.3.pli: Pubbakehesā, māgaṇḍiya, arahantehi sammāsambuddhehi gāthā bhāsitā:
mn75:21.3.eng: For this verse was recited by the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the past:

mn75:21.6.eng: Of paths, the ultimate is eightfold—

mn75:21.7.eng: it’s safe, and leads to freedom from death.’

mn75:21.8.eng: These days it has gradually become a verse used by ordinary people.

mn75:21.9.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana, māgaṇḍiya, kāyo rogabhūto gaṇḍabhūto sallabhūto aghabhūto ābādhabhūto, so tvaṃ imaṃ kāyaṃ rogabhūtaṃ gaṇḍabhūtaṃ sallabhūtaṃ aghabhūtaṃ ābādhabhūtaṃ:
mn75:21.9.eng: But Māgaṇḍiya, this body is a disease, a boil, a dart, a gloom, an affliction. Yet you say of this body:

mn75:21.10.pli: ‘idantaṃ, bho gotama, ārogyaṃ, idantaṃ nibbānan’ti vadesi.
mn75:21.10.eng: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment!’

mn75:21.11.pli: Tañhi te, māgaṇḍiya, ariyaṃ cakkhuṃ natthi yena tvaṃ ariyena cakkhunā ārogyaṃ jāneyyāsi, nibbānaṃ passeyyāsī”ti.
mn75:21.11.eng: Māgaṇḍiya, you don’t have the noble vision by which you might know health and see extinguishment.”

mn75:22.1.eng: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama

mn75:22.2.pli: Pahoti me bhavaṃ gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ ārogyaṃ jāneyyaṃ, nibbānaṃ passeyyan”ti.
mn75:22.2.eng: is capable of teaching me so that I can know health and see extinguishment.”

mn75:22.3.eng: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.

mn75:22.4.pli: so na passeyya kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṃ, na passeyya tārakarūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.
mn75:22.4.eng: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.

mn75:22.5.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn75:22.5.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn75:22.6.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto bhesajjaṃ kareyya.
mn75:22.6.eng: The surgeon would make medicine for them,

mn75:22.7.pli: So taṃ bhesajjaṃ āgamma na cakkhūni uppādeyya, na cakkhūni visodheyya.
mn75:22.7.eng: but when they used it their eyes were not cured and they still could not see clearly.

mn75:22.9.pli: nanu so vejjo yāvadeva kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti?
mn75:22.9.eng: Wouldn’t that doctor just get weary and frustrated?”

mn75:22.11.pli: “Evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, ahañce te dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ:
mn75:22.11.eng: “In the same way, suppose I were to teach you the Dhamma, saying:

mn75:22.12.pli: ‘idantaṃ ārogyaṃ, idantaṃ nibbānan’ti, so tvaṃ ārogyaṃ na jāneyyāsi, nibbānaṃ na passeyyāsi.
mn75:22.12.eng: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment.’ But you might not know health or see extinguishment,

mn75:22.13.pli: So mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
mn75:22.13.eng: which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”

mn75:23.1.eng: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama

mn75:23.2.pli: Pahoti me bhavaṃ gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ ārogyaṃ jāneyyaṃ, nibbānaṃ passeyyan”ti.
mn75:23.2.eng: is capable of teaching me so that I can know health and see extinguishment.”

mn75:23.3.eng: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.

mn75:23.4.pli: so na passeyya kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṃ, na passeyya tārakarūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.
mn75:23.4.eng: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.

mn75:23.5.eng: They might hear a sighted person saying:

mn75:23.6.pli: ‘chekaṃ vata, bho, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti.
mn75:23.6.eng: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’

mn75:23.7.eng: They’d go in search of white cloth.

mn75:23.8.pli: Tamenaṃ aññataro puriso telamalikatena sāhuḷicīrena vañceyya:
mn75:23.8.eng: But someone would cheat them with a dirty, soiled garment, saying:

mn75:23.9.pli: ‘idaṃ te, ambho purisa, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti.
mn75:23.9.eng: ‘Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’

mn75:23.10.eng: They’d take it and put it on.

mn75:23.11.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn75:23.11.eng: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn75:23.12.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto bhesajjaṃ kareyya—
mn75:23.12.eng: The surgeon would make medicine for them:

mn75:23.13.eng: emetics, purgatives, ointment, counter-ointment, or nasal treatment.

mn75:23.14.pli: So taṃ bhesajjaṃ āgamma cakkhūni uppādeyya, cakkhūni visodheyya.
mn75:23.14.eng: And when they used it their eyes would be cured so that they could see clearly.

mn75:23.15.pli: Tassa saha cakkhuppādā yo amusmiṃ telamalikate sāhuḷicīre chandarāgo so pahīyetha.
mn75:23.15.eng: As soon as their eyes were cured they’d lose all desire for that dirty, soiled garment.

mn75:23.16.pli: Tañca naṃ purisaṃ amittatopi daheyya, paccatthikatopi daheyya, api ca jīvitā voropetabbaṃ maññeyya:
mn75:23.16.eng: Then they would consider that person to be no friend, but an enemy, and might even think of murdering them:
mn75:23.16.comm: For “consider (daheyya) as a friend”, see SN 22.85:14.15.

mn75:23.17.pli: ‘dīgharattaṃ vata, bho, ahaṃ iminā purisena telamalikatena sāhuḷicīrena nikato vañcito paluddho—
mn75:23.17.eng: ‘For such a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by that person with this dirty, soiled garment when he said,

mn75:23.18.pli: idaṃ te, ambho purisa, odātaṃ vatthaṃ abhirūpaṃ nimmalaṃ sucī’ti.
mn75:23.18.eng: “Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.”’

mn75:24.1.pli: Evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, ahañce te dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ:
mn75:24.1.eng: In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, suppose I were to teach you the Dhamma, saying:

mn75:24.2.eng: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment.’

mn75:24.3.pli: So tvaṃ ārogyaṃ jāneyyāsi, nibbānaṃ passeyyāsi.
mn75:24.3.eng: You might know health and see extinguishment.

mn75:24.4.pli: Tassa te saha cakkhuppādā yo pañcasupādānakkhandhesu chandarāgo so pahīyetha;
mn75:24.4.eng: And as soon as your vision arises you might give up desire for the five grasping aggregates.

mn75:24.6.pli: ‘dīgharattaṃ vata bho ahaṃ iminā cittena nikato vañcito paluddho.
mn75:24.6.eng: ‘For such a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by this mind.

mn75:24.7.pli: Ahañhi rūpaṃyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṃ, vedanaṃyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṃ, saññaṃyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṃ, saṅkhāreyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṃ, viññāṇaṃyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṃ.
mn75:24.7.eng: For what I have been grasping is only form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

mn75:24.8.pli: Tassa me upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti;
mn75:24.8.eng: My grasping is a requirement for continued existence. Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
mn75:24.8.comm: The text integrates the aggregates and dependent origination (also at SN 22.80:9.10).

mn75:24.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’”

mn75:25.1.eng: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama

mn75:25.2.pli: Pahoti me bhavaṃ gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ imamhā āsanā anandho vuṭṭhaheyyan”ti.
mn75:25.2.eng: is capable of teaching me so that I can rise from this seat cured of blindness.”

mn75:25.3.eng: “Well then, Māgaṇḍiya, you should associate with true persons.

mn75:25.4.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, sappurise bhajissasi tato tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, saddhammaṃ sossasi;
mn75:25.4.eng: When you associate with true persons, you will hear the true teaching.

mn75:25.5.pli: yato kho tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, saddhammaṃ sossasi tato tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, dhammānudhammaṃ paṭipajjissasi;
mn75:25.5.eng: When you hear the true teaching, you’ll practice in line with the teaching.

mn75:25.6.pli: yato kho tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, dhammānudhammaṃ paṭipajjissasi tato tvaṃ, māgaṇḍiya, sāmaṃyeva ñassasi, sāmaṃ dakkhissasi—
mn75:25.6.eng: When you practice in line with the teaching, you’ll know and see for yourself:

mn75:25.8.pli: idha rogā gaṇḍā sallā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
mn75:25.8.eng: And here is where diseases, boils, and darts cease without anything left over.’

mn75:25.9.pli: Tassa me upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti;
mn75:25.9.eng: When my grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

mn75:25.10.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”

mn75:26.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn75:26.1.eng: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya said to him,

mn75:26.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn75:26.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn75:26.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn75:26.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn75:26.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
mn75:26.5.eng: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

mn75:27.1.pli: “Yo kho, māgaṇḍiya, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ, so cattāro māse parivasati; catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
mn75:27.1.eng: “Māgaṇḍiya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.

mn75:27.2.eng: However, I recognize individual differences in this matter.”

mn75:27.3.pli: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhantā upasampadaṃ cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya; ahaṃ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi, catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu, upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
mn75:27.3.eng: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”

mn75:28.1.pli: Alattha kho māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
mn75:28.1.eng: And the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

mn75:28.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā māgaṇḍiyo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
mn75:28.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Māgaṇḍiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn75:28.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
mn75:28.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

mn75:28.4.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā māgaṇḍiyo arahataṃ ahosīti.
mn75:28.4.eng: And Venerable Māgaṇḍiya became one of the perfected.
